00:33:28.300 | - Well, and almost like, it's all going to be okay,
00:33:30.940 | somebody-- - Yeah, and I knew it wasn't.
00:33:34.060 | No, no, you go-- - Unless you--
00:33:36.220 | - Unless you make it okay, it ain't gonna be okay.
00:33:38.960 | - Are you able to forgive her, your mom?
00:33:45.760 | - My boundary with my mom,
00:33:47.880 | the reason I've not spoken with her,
00:33:50.080 | over two years ago, I started this legal career of mine,
00:33:55.080 | I've been the guy who has, I spent a lot of time
00:33:59.720 | thinking about my past and those choices
00:34:02.260 | and what brought those choices around.
00:34:04.240 | So I'm big about taking responsibility for my actions.
00:34:06.780 | I truly am, I think it's really important
00:34:08.240 | you have to do that.
00:34:09.560 | Well, my mom, not so much.
00:34:12.560 | So I was talking to her, you know,
00:34:14.720 | and I would start saying, you know,
00:34:16.280 | she would start the conversation talking about
00:34:19.320 | she didn't understand why Denise

00:50:20.940 | It gets worse than that though,
00:50:21.980 | if you look at business email compromise, all right?
00:50:24.220 | So the way a business email compromise typically works
00:50:26.760 | is the attacker will find a payroll person, find a CEO.
00:50:31.540 | He will fashion a spear phishing email,
00:50:34.060 | which is that's a phishing attack
00:50:35.860 | that's targeting one specific individual, all right?
00:50:38.980 | So he'll fashion a spear phishing email.
00:50:40.740 | And the way he does that is he pulls all the information
00:50:43.820 | he possibly can on that person, all right, that CEO.
00:50:48.820 | Maybe he'll spear that CEO just to get
00:50:54.220 | their login credentials to their email,
00:50:57.100 | just to read the emails.
00:50:58.140 | And he'll go in there and he'll start reading
00:50:59.940 | all these emails.

00:51:02.980 | to the payroll department, see what that relationship is.
00:51:06.100 | Are they talking about their kids?
00:51:07.580 | Talking about relationships, talking about vacation.
00:51:09.500 | What are they talking about?
00:51:10.460 | How are they talking?
00:51:11.300 | Are they friendly?
00:51:12.340 | Are they sterile?
00:51:13.300 | What are they doing, all right?
00:51:15.060 | So then he decides, well, I'm gonna go ahead
00:51:17.060 | and spear phish the payroll department as well.
00:51:20.020 | So then he spear phishes them, gets those credentials.
00:51:22.580 | At the same time, he creates a Unicode domain
00:51:25.700 | in whatever the company name is, all right?
00:51:27.700 | So instead of that English alphabet I,
00:51:29.740 | he's got that Russian letter that looks like an I,
00:51:32.220 | but without the dot on top, all right?
00:51:35.220 | Comes back into the email, into the payroll email,
00:51:38.340 | blocks the real CEO's email, replaces that
00:51:41.820 | with the Unicode email that he's got,
00:51:44.180 | and then sends out a message using the correct language,
00:51:48.900 | the correct relationships, everything else,
00:51:51.060 | and says, hey, we're updating our account status.
00:51:53.940 | I need you to send this payment instead of this over here.
00:51:57.020 | They've set up a new account.
00:51:58.100 | Send all payments over here now.
00:51:59.820 | And that is business email compromise in a nutshell,
00:52:02.620 | all right, works great.
00:52:04.460 | - Probably the larger the organization,
00:52:06.580 | the more susceptible to that kind of attack,
00:52:10.140 | 'cause there's a distribution of responsibility
00:52:14.820 | to where you're more likely to believe that,
00:52:16.860 | okay, this other person is responsible.
00:52:18.980 | I'm sure they secured everything.
00:52:21.020 | - Absolutely.
00:52:21.940 | - I'm okay listening to this.
00:52:23.340 | - So that's business email compromise,
00:52:25.940 | and those crimes, and that's one of the things
00:52:27.780 | you see about cybercrime.
00:52:28.820 | Cybercrime's not really sophisticated.

01:10:14.440 | And it was a third party company
01:10:16.680 | that was doing all the telemarketing,
01:10:17.800 | made really good money doing that.
01:10:19.720 | That job ended and then they pivoted over
01:10:22.880 | to working with Kiwanis Clubs,
01:10:25.180 | selling food baskets to the food banks and everything.
01:10:29.320 | So I stole the phone list
01:10:32.480 | and started up my own Kiwanis Club
01:10:34.880 | and would do the telemarketing,
01:10:36.760 | go out twice a week and pick up checks.
01:10:39.440 | Well, what happened was is I'm going out
01:10:42.760 | picking up checks, go knock on a door.
01:10:46.240 | Turns out one of the persons that I had called
01:10:48.480 | was a law enforcement officer.

01:10:52.960 | I'm like, "I'm with the Kiwanis Club."
01:10:55.400 | And he's like, "No, you're not."

01:11:41.520 | - I would find somebody that had like a stereo system
01:11:43.680 | on eBay, something like that,

01:14:27.680 | including self, learns.

01:25:51.180 | that if you're gonna be successful in this,
01:25:54.340 | you should have people you trust.
01:25:56.940 | Is he right on that?
01:25:58.000 | - Oh, he's absolutely right.
01:26:00.060 | He's absolutely right.
01:26:00.900 | - So, you have to have, this is like mob.
01:26:03.680 | - You have to--
01:26:04.520 | - You have to have an inner circle that you trust.
01:26:07.780 | - I'm sure you've probably heard me say this before.
01:26:11.420 | Successful cyber crime, all right?
01:26:14.580 | There are three necessities to being successful online
01:26:17.580 | if you're a criminal.
01:26:18.540 | Three necessities are gathering data,
01:26:21.080 | committing the crime, and then cashing it out.
01:26:24.260 | All three of those necessities have to work in conjunction.
01:26:26.700 | If they don't, the crime fails.
01:26:28.420 | The problem, and it's a huge problem,
01:26:30.740 | is that one guy can't do all three things.
01:26:34.100 | You've got the people who gather the data.
01:26:37.020 | Basically, the general store sells people
01:26:39.700 | who sell PII, credit card logins, data tools.
01:26:44.540 | They always sell the spoofed phone numbers
01:26:46.260 | and the RDPs, stuff like that.
01:26:48.620 | A lot of the times, those people don't know
01:26:49.860 | how to commit the crime, and those people certainly
01:26:51.940 | don't know how to launder the money out
01:26:53.260 | and put cash in pocket.
01:26:54.660 | So, you've got, either because of a skill level,
01:26:58.060 | sometimes a geographic location,
01:27:00.180 | limits what that individual can do, all right?
01:27:03.300 | So, you have to rely on people who are good
01:27:06.220 | in areas where you are not in order
01:27:08.620 | for that crime to succeed.
01:27:10.660 | And that means you have to trust those people.

01:32:42.420 | So, on the back of your credit or debit card,
01:32:44.500 | there's a magnetic stripe.

01:33:21.580 | shows up on the screen of the cashier in front of you.

03:09:32.080 | All right, so in federal prison, you gotta have a job.
03:09:35.240 | Everybody works.
03:09:36.080 | Doesn't matter what you do, but you gotta work.
03:09:37.560 | I got a job in education teaching a lit class.
03:09:41.200 | Every Wednesday, 6 to 8.30 p.m., lit.
03:09:45.280 | And had all, every area on the compound

03:09:52.400 | And did we teach lit?
03:09:54.840 | No, we taught fraud every Wednesday, 6 to 8.30 p.m.
03:09:59.840 | That's how I didn't get my ass beaten.
03:10:02.120 | And my other job, I had two jobs with them.
03:10:04.680 | The other job, you get to the point, it's weird, man.
03:10:07.800 | You get to the point, people walking off the bus.
03:10:11.680 | You know immediately two groups of people.
03:10:13.960 | You know who the bank robbers are, immediately.
03:10:16.720 | Just by them walking off the bus,
03:10:18.080 | you're like, "That motherfucker's a bank robber."
03:10:20.360 | And you know who the pedophiles are, immediately.
03:10:23.560 | So my job as the white guy
03:10:26.320 | was to approach the white pedophiles
03:10:28.720 | and have a conversation.
03:10:29.840 | And the conversation was basically,
03:10:30.960 | "Hey, don't know what you in here for.
03:10:34.600 | "Don't care what you in here for.
03:10:36.880 | "But if you got some sort of fucked up charge,
03:10:40.000 | "you need to tell me.
03:10:42.000 | "If you tell me, everything's gonna be all right.
03:10:46.240 | "If you don't tell me, you see those guys over there?
03:10:49.380 | "If you start to associate with them,
03:10:51.120 | "or they start to talk to you,
03:10:52.520 | "and then they find out you're in here on something,
03:10:55.400 | "they're gonna kill you."
03:10:57.240 | And what are the things?
03:10:58.120 | Pedophile.
03:10:59.600 | Pedophile, rapist, anything that harms children,
03:11:02.640 | harms women, anything like that.
03:11:04.720 | There are, it's like the mob.
03:11:07.120 | There's rules, there's an ethical code.
03:11:10.440 | Even if you have the division between races on all that,
03:11:15.160 | you still have these lines drawn.
03:11:17.760 | And there's a hierarchy too.
03:11:19.680 | Very, very much so.
03:11:20.520 | And what that looks like in prison,
03:11:22.000 | depending on the, it depends on the security class
03:11:25.080 | that you're in, what level prison.
03:11:27.640 | But at that prison, what that looked like was,
03:11:31.040 | you're not allowed to talk to anybody.
03:11:33.360 | You're not allowed to watch television.
03:11:35.520 | You can go to the library.
03:11:37.300 | You don't associate with anyone except your own type.
03:11:40.740 | If you do anything like this, we will kill you.
03:11:44.640 | If someone wants to extort you, we will do that too,
03:11:49.200 | and you won't tell on us, or we'll kill you.
03:11:52.680 | So that's the way that works at that point.
03:11:55.480 | And everybody quickly learns this.
03:11:58.120 | Quickly, quickly.
03:11:59.680 | And so typically the guys would say,
03:12:02.360 | "I just wanna do my own time."
03:12:03.700 | That would be the line.
03:12:05.120 | And it's like, okay, don't mess with him, all right?
03:12:08.440 | Every now and then you'd have somebody lie,
03:12:11.760 | and that would come with those types of consequences.
03:12:14.560 | I got to see, while I was there,
03:12:17.740 | saw two people murdered,
03:12:20.040 | saw, went through three prison riots,
03:12:23.160 | and through my entire tenure in prison,
03:12:25.200 | saw four suicides.
03:12:26.960 | The people who got killed, it was,
03:12:29.840 | so we had, outside you had this track,
03:12:32.000 | third of a mile track.
03:12:33.420 | You walk it counterclockwise,
03:12:35.720 | and inside of the track you got two handball courts.
03:12:38.200 | So of an evening, it happened both times,
03:12:41.620 | you, all of us would be walking, doing our exercises,
03:12:45.160 | and at the top of the key, like a flock of birds,
03:12:47.680 | you'd see all the inmates start to migrate down
03:12:51.080 | toward the gate.
03:12:52.000 | So the first time you see that, you see that migration,
03:12:55.240 | you look up in the distance,
03:12:56.340 | and this other, one of the inmates got another inmate down,
03:12:59.900 | and he's just hammering his head right into the pavement,
03:13:02.840 | like that right there.

03:13:05.600 | because a guard may get hurt.

03:13:11.660 | until everything's over.
03:13:12.500 | By that point, the guy doesn't have a head.
03:13:15.260 | They shut the compound down, and this is what happens.
03:13:17.740 | So you shut the entire compound down,
03:13:20.020 | they make two lines of the inmates,
03:13:22.740 | and what happens is, the inmate walks into a room,
03:13:25.780 | they shut the door behind the inmate,
03:13:27.300 | guard asks them two questions.
03:13:28.660 | First question is, did you see anything?
03:13:30.340 | The answer is no.

03:13:35.460 | Answer is no.
03:13:36.620 | Guard then says, get the fuck out.
03:13:38.480 | And that's it.

03:13:42.980 | is automatically suspect.

03:26:40.700 | And to this day, Lex, I know what my triggers are.

03:26:50.140 | So I looked at Michelle and I was like,
03:26:51.300 | let me see what I can do.
03:26:53.100 | Signed on to LinkedIn, reached out to this FBI super cop
03:26:56.940 | named Keith Malarski out of the Pittsburgh office.
03:26:58.980 | He was involved with my arrest and some associates
03:27:02.380 | and everything else and sent him a message.
03:27:05.300 | And the message was, hey, I respect everything you did.
03:27:07.820 | Think you did a great job.
03:27:09.780 | By the way, I'd like to be legal.
03:27:12.460 | And dude responded within two hours.
03:27:16.300 | Two hours, he gives me references, advice,
03:27:19.420 | takes me in under his wing, everything else like that.
03:27:22.220 | And from that point, man, it was the head
03:27:24.260 | of the Identity Theft Council did the same thing.
03:27:26.700 | Cardnot Present Group hires me to speak.
03:27:31.540 | Microsoft hires me to consult with them.

03:27:37.580 | in the industry that I was all right from that point.

03:29:34.800 | Cyber crime, a lot of companies that I talk to,

03:29:40.760 | that networking aspect, that trust aspect
03:29:45.840 | of how criminals establish trust with each other,

03:29:52.220 | that's out victimizing them.

03:29:56.260 | that you've got a group of individuals
03:29:58.500 | that are working together to hit you,
03:30:00.200 | but not only hit you,
03:30:01.040 | but they share and exchange information freely.
03:30:04.020 | Companies don't do that.
03:30:05.180 | You've got privacy concerns,
03:30:06.340 | you've got competitive edge concerns, everything else.

03:30:10.780 | like criminals do.

03:30:12.960 | You have to appreciate that.
03:30:14.980 | You have to understand that big statistic
03:30:17.940 | that 90% of your attacks use known exploits.

03:30:21.820 | it's the shit we do know about.
